item.title: 1.1. Introduction and Overview
item.description: Contents Overview Slides Overview An introduction to the course. Slides Lecture Slides

item.title: Assignments
item.description: Grade Calculator Use this tool to calculate your final course grade and predict what grades you would need on remaining assignments to obtain a desired course grade. Position Paper Each of you will write a short position paper on a topic from our applications at the end of the semester (e.g. on antitrust, automation, data as labor, etc). Participation and Discussion At the end of most lessons, we will hold a discussion.

item.title: Reference
item.description: Contents Tips for Success Look here over the course of the semester for resources, links, and tips on how to succeed in the course, how to write well, and other things of interest related to economic development. Tips for Success Take notes. On paper. Really. Studies show that using pen and paper trump taking notes on a device. The main reason is because you cannot possibly write down everything I am saying by hand.

item.title: Schedule
item.description: This page contains all of the following resources for each class meeting: Readings include textbook chapters and occasional journal articles Assignments are due by the beginning of class unless otherwise stated Class materials contain extra explanations, math/statistical properties & proofs, and other helpful resourcesThese “online appendices” keep the slides nice and de-cluttered! Slides are “Xaringan” presentations in html that can be opened in any browserFile > Print > Save as PDF if you wish to download them

item.title: Syllabus
item.description: Download as PDF Last Updated: January 15, 2020 Industrial Organization⊕Instructor Dr. Ryan Safner 118 Rosenstock safner@hood.edu @ryansafner Office hours: MW 3:15–5:00PM Course TuTh January 15–May 8, 2020 2:00–3:15PM 101 Rosenstock is one of the most common fields of applied microeconomics. It traditionally studies business firms and their relationship to the market–how they make economic decisions, how they are affected by government regulation, how they strategically interact with one another–and how these change in markets that are more or less competitive–monopoly, oligopoly, monopolistic competition, or perfect competition, often with a close connection to antitrust law.
